How fat is your piggy bank? An exploration into the predictability of financial well-being using Support Vector Machines
Utilizing Political Campaign Contribution Networks to Identify Political Affiliations and Important Actors in US Elections
Financial Well Being
item.description: One of the most commonly used tools in public policy and social sciences are surveys. In the absence of directly observable actions, self-reported surveys become indispensable in identifying and classifying high-risk individuals. One such survey, which identifies individuals under financial duress, is the subject of our project. Using Support Vector Machines (SVM), a supervised machine learning method, we investigate whether indirect information from our survey dataset determines a respondent’s financial well-being.

item.title: Building Engineers and Mentors
item.description: Building Engineers and Mentors at UCLA provides K-12 students across the greater Los Angeles area with engaging activities that promote interest in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). The curriculum is available on their website.

Environmental Education
item.description: The Los Angeles Audubonâ€™s environmental education program at Kenneth Hahn State Recreation Area educates local students about the outdoors. Interns lead elementary and middle school students on guided walks with educational stations. The curriculum includes lessons on photosynthesis, ecosystems, ecology, and geology depending on grade level.

item.title: Political Donations in the United States
item.description: Research on United States political donations

item.title: Women in Technology
item.description: Women in Technology is a chapter of the Association for Computing Machinery at Santa Monica College. I started the club in 2013 with Elizabeth Gross and served as Vice President. While I was an officer, we created robots, taught at the local middle school, organized the Computer Science Department’s Open House, and recieved grants from Google and other organizations.

I study applied mathematics with a specialization in computing at UCLA. I have studied fluid dynamics, financial scores, and United States political donation data. I currently research Gang Reduction and Youth Development. I love using math to solve puzzles and real-world problems.
